Contain your enthusiasm, stick to less than 500 characters for the descrption.

description.en-US:
What’s New

- From today, you'll notice a shiny new app button that matches our new logo. You can read more about it on our blog at SlackHQ.com. Change! Everyone loves it. (Having said that, nothing about Slack or how you use it has changed. Just the button.) 

Bug Fixes

- Users signing in with Single Sign-On would see the same message twice when logging in.
- Users signing in with Single Sign-On would see the same message twice when logging in. This will not happen any more.
- When trying to select a portion of a code-formatted block of text (text formatted with \` or \`\`\` at either end), some characters were proving slippery and hard to select. You can now copy and paste to your heart's content.
- Several random, rare crashes — on launch and at other times — have been eliminated. More random and rare crashes inevitably exist, of course, and as soon as we know what they are, we'll eliminate those too.
- The full screen shortcut was mistakenly listed as ‘Ctrl+F’ instead of ‘Ctrl+Shift+F’ in the "View" menu. We both apologize for this and hope that, because of it, someone out there discovered 'Ctrl+F' as a useful shortcut for searching the channel that you're in. Always look on the bright side of bugs.

Bug Fixes

- An important security update. Security updates are always important. This is one of those.

Bug Fixes

- We got so excited about your emoji we kept requesting them, particularly at the moment you switched channels. This caused all manner of slowness. We've since bottled our enthusiasm, and now request emoji exactly one (1) time.

Bug Fixes

- You're nearly finished signing in when suddenly – bonk – you're brought back to the first page. Hey, what gives? Please accept our apologies and, in this version, 100% less bonking
- Entering characters from the accent menu no longer inserts an extra character. Voilà señorita: that souffleé is now an (edible) soufflé.

What’s New

- Previously in Slack app releases: we fixed the Japanese input in 2.6.3. Then we re-broke it in 2.8.0. And now it’s fixed again. Stay tuned for the next thrilling installment.
- An important Electron update improving security. A precautionary measure, but it’s always good to be up to date.

What’s New

- Myriad improvements for the people of Enterprise Grid, including quicker Quick Switching, better proxy support, and direct message draft syncing across multiple workspaces (meaning that whichever workspace you started typing that message in, you can finish in another.)

Bug Fixes

- Unread badges were occasionally unreliable or inconsistent, so we tweaked a few doohickeys to improve them. It worked.
- Smoothed some wrinkles in the loading of Slack calls and boosted general under-the-hood call performance while we were in there.
- We tinkered with the workspace sign-in flow, updating how we handle errors and improving magic link support.
- Copying email links now does what you’d expect (as long as you were expecting it to copy the email link. If you were expecting it to do something like file your taxes for you, you are still out of luck).
- Slack will no longer interrupt macOS when restarting or shutting down.
- After changing displays, pinch-to-zoom gestures will no longer insist on continuing to zoom the app when you pinch.
- Twelve crashes have been fixed. Yes. 12. If you were unlucky enough to experience the full dozen, please accept a) this imaginary medal and b) our sincere apologies.

Bug Fixes

- All updates are important, of course. This one contains security updates, and as we know, they’re the most important kind of all.

What’s New

- Slack is now a little faster, thanks to a few small but important changes.
- Admins now have a little more control when configuring the ability to auto-update with a "plist". We've checked, and that's definitely the word. Admins: you apparently know what that means.

Bug Fixes

- Drag and dropping files into Slack is much more stable now. Phew.
- If you do need, for some reason, to reset the app data, this is now a smoother process than before.
- Those in many workspaces will find that their icons are now more pleasingly aligned in the sidebar. It's a small thing, but very pleasing.
- When DND is enabled, we no longer bounce the icon in the dock. Because DND means DND.
- The process of updating Slack is now more stable — and we now more helpfully explain why we're asking for permissions to do that update.
- Notifications were not making sounds that might notify you 100% of the time. Honestly, they had ONE job. They now perform it.
- Customized Slack shortcuts on macOS that sometimes weren't working now do the thing you intended (and apologies that that wasn't the case for some).
- Hardware acceleration can now be turned off without foregrounding Slack. If you know what that means, you'll know it's a good thing. And if you don't — it still is! And thank you for reading anyway.

Bug Fixes

- We tuned up the engine and gave the interiors a thorough clean. Everything is now running smoothly again.

(Yes! All of these release notes have been lovingly pillaged from Slack's [brilliant release notes](https://slack.com/intl/en-au/release-notes/mac) in order to fill the content void. Lorem Ipsum? Pfft.)

What’s New

- Batten the hatches! The app sandbox is now enabled for all web content. This is a fancy way of saying we’ve dialed up the security of the app. It wasn’t unsafe before, but it’s double safe now.
- A preference that allows you to choose a unique save location per download, instead of choosing a folder for all of them. For the choosy types.

Bug Fixes

- Downloading app updates is less prone to timing out on slow networks, as we’ve extended the timeout to something reasonable.
- The Close button has returned to its rightful place on notifications, for all your dismissing needs.
- If you found yourself, in some distant past, trying to start a song on Spotify with your keyboard’s play button, and it did not respond to your command while Slack was front and center, pesky hardware media keys were the problem. And this version is the cure.
- The app should be less spicy to your CPU when you’re viewing certain network error pages.
- When a download completes, we’ll show an in-app prompt rather than a bothersome system notification.

question.en-US: How do I set up my developer environment?

answer.en-US:
There's no explicit sandbox or developer environment available to work against. Instead, you'll need to use a workspace you've created or are a member of.

It's best to keep your integration or app's ownership contained within the workspace that is responsible for it.

question.en-US: How are incoming webhooks, slash commands, and bot users different?

answer.en-US:
All three integration types allow you to post messages within a channel but differ in how those messages are triggered and how users interact with your app.

You can use all of these integration types together in your Slack app.

Of course we want Slack fully functional for users and developers at all times. Here are some tips in the unfortunate event you're having trouble and need to determine exactly how broken Slack might be.

question.en-US: How do I authenticate my requests to Slack?

answer.en-US:
When working with Slack apps or Web API, you'll often need to send access tokens, also known as bearer tokens, along with inbound requests using the token query parameter.

Some of the tokens you'll be given while going through the integration creation process. Other tokens you obtain by sending users through the OAuth 2.0 authentication flow.

question.en-US: How do I use API methods with my bot user token?

answer.en-US:
When a Slack App is approved that contains a bot user, you're awarded two tokens. The bot user token is for performing certain actions directly as the bot user, like posting a message or connecting to the real time messaging API.

If you want to make Web API calls more generally, based on the scopes you've negotiated, you'll want to use the broader token you were awarded at approval time.

question.en-US: Why does Slack never reach my slash command URL?

answer.en-US:
Typically, if Slack cannot reach your slash command URL it's because it's either inaccessible, does not have a valid, verifiable SSL certificate, or because our request is timing out for some reason.

Slack invokes slash command URLs from its servers rather than from a Slack client app like Slack for Mac. This means that the URL we're trying to reach must be accessible to Slack's servers.

To determine whether your certificate is valid, consider using this tool provided by SSL Labs.

question.en-US: How is the API rate limited?

answer.en-US:
Slack rate limits all aspects of platform use with many factors. Rate limits are currently unpublished. Review our rate limiting documentation for more detail.

The guiding spirit of Slack's rate limiting is to ensure that teams are able to communicate effortlessly and without distraction.

question.en-US: How do I connect to a websocket?

answer.en-US:
The first step is making a typical HTTP request to the rtm.connect method. Within that response, you'll find a url field beginning with the URI protocol wss://.

Then, use a Websocket client to open a long-lived connection to that time-sensitive URL. While the connection is open, you'll be streamed events associated with the workspace you're connecting on behalf of and can in turn send messages.

question.en-US: How do I validate a slash command's origin?

answer.en-US: Keep track of the validation tokens and team IDs Slack gives you when commands are created and teams approve your app. Always validate that the token field in an incoming slash command request has been issued to you by Slack and scope your data for that workspace.

details.en-US: 90,000 bonus points when you spend $3,000 on everyday purchases within the first 60 days of account opening and 30,000 bonus points when you keep your card for over 12 months.

body.en-US: The Faux Card is the easiest way for everyone in your company to handle expenses. Instantly provision cards, manage your company's spending in real-time, and get credit increases as your business grows. Rather than deal with complex rewards programs, you'll simply get extra cash back on the categories where you spent the most. It's the corporate card we wanted for ourselves.
All you need to apply is a Faux account—no paperwork or personal guarantee required. Get up and running with a virtual card in minutes.

title.en-US: Credit limits that grow with you

body.en-US: Your credit limit is determined by your payment processing and bank history. As your business grows, your credit line can too.
Upload your logo right from the Dashboard to make your corporate card look and feel like your brand.

Find vulnerabilities that other tools miss
All your code and documentation in one place

description.en-US: OSS all the way down. (Well, mostly.)

content.value: Some notes on the tech, tooling and infrastructure used to build out this POC as a complete solution, with some details on the decisions and trade-offs made.
There are two essential features required from a front-end framework in this stack:
— Render views on your server of components and routes along with your headless CMS data on demand. Critical for allowing content authors to preview new changes and developers to iterate fast

— Vastly simplify your ops and streamline your processes by having your framework prerender your site and deploy it to a static host. All the benefits of component-based development with all the SEO benefits of prerendered views.
Next performs both functions, and also happens to have a near magical development experience:
Hot code reloading — Instant feedback in developer environments
, routes only load with just the libraries and code they need, nothing more.
Filesystem based routing — Intuitive filesystem API for building static and dynamic routes
Universal rendering — Prerender views ahead of time for near-instant user page load, adding interactivity when the bundle rehydrates on the client.
— Prefetch data for the next page load for snappier page load times
Back-end agnostic data sources — Swap out your data sources with ease.
show the same site deployed with eight different headless CMS providers as a data source and the minimal changes required to switch providers.
— Easily build and develop APIs that can be deployed as serverless functions
Zero-config: Most of these features/benefits come with minimal, if any, configuration
If the platform were to proceed with this kind of stack for future projects, I couldn't recommend Next.js enough.
, but the ecosystem is still nascent. If there was a goal of having the smallest bundle size and no runtime overhead, I'd opt for Sapper and Svelte hands down.
— A React-based alternative to Next.js, equally as capable with a rich plugin-based ecosystem, though I prefer the simplicity and focus of Next's APIs.
— Ticks the SSG and SSR boxes though with Vue-based components
Pretty standard, but one neat thing about using a headless CMS is I can
, meaning I can get static typing all the way from my data store through to my React props.
Next.js is a React-based framework, though it

. I considered using Preact for this project just to try it out, but to keep things simple and avoid dealing with compatability issues, I opted for React since it has broader support, better tooling, a massive ecosystem and, synthetic events but at the cost of a larger library.

However, in this case application code will dwarf library code and the value of the compromises of Preact vs the smaller bundle size aren't worth it. Preact seems to be targeted at small applications where every kb counts. If the problem was to aggressively minimise bundle size I would opt for a compiled framework like Svelte and Sapper.
Also, project-wide React upgrades would be infrequent enough that the long cache life of libs would negate working around the compromises of  Preact to save one hit of ~30kb.

Tailwind CSS is a highly customizable, low-level CSS framework that gives you all of the building blocks you need to build bespoke designs without any annoying opinionated styles you have to fight to override.
With Tailwind, you essentially get a customizable design system for free. Tailwind makes it easy to do the right thing, enforcing good design practices by default:
easily codify common patterns into higher level abstractions
It's especially the systemisation of all styling values that enables rapid development of UI components.
No longer need to name things or ensure whole teams conform to a naming convention.
Smaller CSS bundle as you're reusing atomic classes across your project.
Worth noting, the markup it produces is kinda ugly at first (long class lists applied to elements), but it's fine once you get used to it. Also, FWIW, it's
The testing strategy for this stack mostly boils down to this:
Write tests. Not too many. Mostly integration —

from Kent C. Dodds expands on the idea, but essentially high confidence that your system will continue to function as intended when you introduce change doesn't necessitate 100% code coverage. And if you're trying to hit arbitrary code coverage, you are more than likely going to be testing implementation detail. Still have tests, but have fewer, higher-signal, higher-value tests, even if they're considered more expensive.

With a static site build system, you can also leverage integration end-to-end tests to perform business critical checks on each build. Since the purpose of most marketing sites, is conversions of prospective customers, it's important that with each change to the site that we identify any errors on the client that prevents completion of sign-up flows.

End-to-end tests are useful for testing longer workflows, especially when they’re critical to your business (such as payments or signups). For these tests, you’d probably want to test how a real browser renders the whole app, fetches data from the real API endpoints, uses sessions and cookies, navigates between different links.

For example, you could have a credit card application suite, testing a predefined flow through to the application form, at which point we hand over responsibility to Forms (we've maintained our contract that users can successfully reach this responsibility 'boundary').
Working with key stakeholders and authors, we can build a suite of business critical end-to-end tests that are kicked off asynchronously in CI on each content rebuild triggered from the CMS.

Cypress is a useful end-to-end test framework with an expressive API that almost reads like natural language. In this project since most the pages / components are static, the specs are mostly just sanity checks, but for the few interactive routes and components (/search, /help), it provides high quality guarantees that the user experience is as intended.

It's worth adding, another benefit of statically generated sites is since they're so lightweight, easily built and served in CI, you can run your e2e test suites against each commit of a release candidate, giving you higher confidence in your changes long before they go live.
I didn't get around to implementing Storybook and setting up Chromatic due to time constraints, but the intent was to leverage Chromatic's visual testing and CI integration to test the
output of components, not just the markup in isolation, which doesn't really guarantee much (looking at you, snapshot testing).

Sidenote: For component-based testing, I think snapshot tests are next-to-useless. At best snapshots alert you to the extent of updates to one component, though the mostly only serve to produce noise in PR diffs, and not much else. Changes to component rendering can be seen in a living style guide / component library and in the visual diffs ran in CI.
seems like an intersting component-management service in this space.)

of headless CMS platforms available, each with it's own set of features and trade-offs, and I'm still in the process of assessing the solution space, but for this POC I decided to use Contentful, mainly as it's perceived as the eminent enterprise solution, often used for replacing monolothic CMS platforms.
There are two other providers that I currently think are viable alternatives:
: I only came across DatoCMS part way through implementing the Contentful-backed POC, but I think is an even better offering than what Contentful currently has.

lays out a good comparison between the two providers, but in short here are some relevant features they offer: Granular roles and permissions, audit logs, GraphQL-first content API, Imgix-backed image API, whitelabelling admin dashboard, modular content blocks.
: Open source solution with a new enterprise offering
10 Headless CMS Options for your JAMstack Website
provides a good overview of the current landscape of headless CMS providers.

With a headless CMS all of your content is already structured and organised. We can leverage this with our search provider by creating more intelligent search results that index the pure content according our predefined schema, rather than scraping content from rendered pages and trying to make sense of the structure.

Also, since we can respond to publish/unpublish events in our headless CMS, we can trigger a rebuild of the search index to run asynchronously, ensuring our search results are always up to date. This is exactly how search works for this stack: a Contentful publish event webhook pushes the updated content directly to Algolia, making the updated results instantly available to the client.
Algolia itself as a product is extremely fast, providing a near-instant reactive search experience, useful monitoring and clear and insightful
. They also provide a great developer experience, with several front-end clients (and many more back-end SDKs).

These weren't critical choices, just services I wanted to explore. Though it's worth pointing out that with a headless CMS-based stack you get this flexibility of choosing the best tool/service for the job, and not being stuck with whatever will integrate with your CMS.
seems like best-in-class in the field.
: Nothing particularly interesting about this choice, though it's worth noting Next.js provides access to performance metrics like Google's new
out of the box, which you can forward to your analytics provider.
looks comprehensive), but still a great, focused product. One neat thing: you can upload source maps to Sentry with each deployment so you have friendly stack traces to work with.
: Didn't get around to integrating this, but they provide a solid video platform, a

Cloudflare Workers is Cloudflare's edge compute solution built on V8's Isolates. (A really interesting tech talk from a Cloudflare tech lead on the architecture and security model of Workers can be found
.) Since the site is entirely static, it can be deployed directly to Cloudflare's CDN via Cloudflare Workers, meaning origin-less deployments! There's
a lot you can do with Workers
, but here are some of the benefits I've found:
Instant rollback: Since your assets are deploy directly to the edge, and there's no need to wait for DNS TTL to expire, deployments and rollbacks are instant
Since there's no origin to revalidate, every request is guaranteed to be as fast as possible
Redirects can be handled at the Edge, no server required
Since Next produces fingerprinted assets, I can also set aggressive cache policies
Simple test and deployment pipeline setup, covering the entire development lifecycle for the project, along with straightforward GitHub event integration. The two main workflows setup:
On content publish / unpublish: Trigger a site rebuild, deploy to Cloudflare Workers, run business critical e2e test suite
On commit: Run static analysis, (linting, type checking), execute e2e test suite, execute a performance audit of the build, send results to the Lighthouse server

Green fields projects can be performant from the beginning, but unless you're actively monitoring the impact of project changes on the end user experience over time, things begin slide. Marketing wants to add a massive third-party analytics script here, a developers adds a time-date formatting library there, someone adds an expensive op on the main thread, and before you know it your once snappy site has slowed to a crawl.

Automated performance testing via Lighthouse helps you start with a high performance baseline, and ensures you don't slip below predefined performance budgets. If someone wants to add something to the site that'll hurt performance the build fails and developers can discuss is it justifiable or are there alternatives that don't impact the user experience? It makes performance hits opt-in, rather than something that suffers over time.
Lighthouse also provides accessibility, SEO, PWA and best practices auditing.
For this project, the Lighthouse server that retains audit history was deployed to Heroku, though since it's containerised, it can be run by any cloud provider.
Every push and pull request receives a shareable URL, enhancing collaboration between stakeholders, designers, developers and a11y. Incredibly simple integration with GitHub.

Nothing particularly special about choosing GCP, I just wanted to try out a different cloud provider. The preview server is containerised, with minimal requirements (can probably run on a T2.Micro), so it can be run with any major public cloud / on most PaaS. Ditto for the build archives, they're static assets so any object storage solution from any cloud provider is sufficient.

description.en-US: An overview of the benefits that a headless CMS-based stack provides

content.value: — By serving a pre-built, optimised static files you get optimal performance.

There are limitations to how much AEM can optimize the customer experience — All code for all components must be loaded when visiting  any single page, regardless if that page is pure text, as we add more  components that experience gets more and more sluggish.
With ahead of time compilation and static site generation workflows, we know ahead of time exactly what is on a page, and can aggressively optimise our static assets.
to begin to badge slow sites
— See note in authoring experience below.
— The abstraction authors work with moves up from the low-level 'atoms' they have to wrangle in AEM to configurable sections /
. There are a few benefits to this:
Rapid and consistent authoring across the org
: Pages simply become assemblies of designer and a11y-approved content sections.
Less time duplicating the same content patterns repeatedly
: Those patterns become the configurable content sections available to the authors.
: Design language can now be enforced at the block/section level.

: Accessibility sign-off on components at the atomic-level, but there's no guarantees they're assembled with accessibility in mind. Front-loading the work of assembling section templates and having them approved by a11y gives us greater guarantees on the quality of the experience of
Related to 3 and 4: Authors aren't UX/UI designers, nor are they accessibility experts. This model leaves them to focus solely on content authoring.
— Authors just pick a single master image to use, not a rendition, developers ensure the optimum version of the image is served across all viewports.
— No more duplicating content across the site with well-structured, resuable content models
— Moving to automated releases outside of publishing hours, we can provide an uninterrupted authoring experience.

Headless CMS providers can provide a better SLA / more uptime than we currently provide to authors: Assuming a very modest 14 days of NAB stack content moratoriums a year, we provide author access for 96% of the year.
Business critical process checks on each build

Since the purpose of most marketing sites, is conversions of prospective customers, it's important that with each change to the site that we identify any errors on the client that prevents completion of sign-up flows.
This is made possible by the fact that static sites can be generated and served directly in CI.

For example, you could have a credit card application suite, testing a predefined flow through to the application form, at which point we hand over responsibility to Forms (we've maintained our contract that users can successfully reach this responsibility 'boundary').
Working with key stakeholders and authors, we can build a suite of business critical end-to-end tests that are kicked off asynchronously in CI on each content rebuild triggered from the CMS.

(This mainly stems from seeing incidents where customers couldn't access particular sign-up forms (broken links, client-side errors), and those errors not being detected until a stakeholder brought it to our attention.)
Build reactive components faster and painlessly

— The current model of manual DOM manipulations to build out our components hamstrings our ability to deliver fast and easily make component updates in the future. Adopting a declarative framework would improve developer velocity and ability to deliver change.
— Composing multiple components together is a breeze once the 'atomic' components are built out
Faster development with a base set of primitives to compose
Faster turnarounds that enables more experimentation with one-off designs / layouts    and analytics to see how well it's received
the cost of change and developer productivity with the additional mental overhead it adds. The model should reduce the amount of code required to get things done.
Instant, canonical dev environments with Docker
— No more "it works on my machine"
and this model's release process, there's no longer the pain of managing and juggling long-lived release branches. Deploy individual features straight to prod.
Faster iteration on content models with Authors
— The ability to quickly try out new content models, iterate, develop and simultaneously gather author feedback is a game changer.

My experience whilst developing the POC: Whenever I felt a content model was a tad awkward or missing something, or the type wasn't right, I could update the model within seconds in the Contentful dashboard, export my type definitions and continue on with development.

Operationally inexpensive, significantly lower cloud costs — This stack essentially eliminates our current cloud bill. All you're paying for is a preview container for SSR running on minimal resources and amazingly cheap object storage for build archives.
No need for complex and expensive infrastructure: A whole VPC -> An S3 bucket and container.
Essentially zero maintenance overhead — Minimal monitoring or devops required
Simplified deployment flow — Build the site, push to the CDN. That's it.
Prod support essentially no longer required — No server means no running instances to respond to outages and incidents for, no 500 errors, no activations stuck in workflow.
Ways the front-end can fail due to dynamic CMS content aren't an issue
— Groupstack hosts 10+ sites. If there's any problem with  AEM, all sites are down, creating a single point of failure. Making each site a separate static site eliminates that risk entirely.
AEM is complicated product, requiring specialist knowledge to do anything beyond basic tasks.
Eliminates the 'moving parts' of our current stack.
— A headless platform / SaaS solution means upgrades come automatically
Allocate the money and resources otherwise sunk into these processes to a product backed by a company that manages content infrastructure at scale, you'll get a better ROI
— This model enables smaller, more focused releases and the ability to ship changes to production fast. No more large, high-risk releases.
No server required for us to serve requests means no server to exploit or patch. And as the application is containerised, maintaining patch compliance is straightforward.
Attack surface significantly reduced with a serverless architecture, eliminates the entire queue of current security work
— Deploy your statically generated assets directly to the edge, no server required

More fail-safe — With an origin like a traditional CMS server you can have load issues with the server (an actual incident that happened), inability of CDN to connect to the origin. Those problems are now eliminated.
Every request is as fast as possible; no additional RTT to check if the resource on the origin has been updated. i.e. each request will always hit the CDN cache
Instant rollbacks: Bad deployment? Redeploy the last stable build to the edge, no waiting for the DNS TTL to expire
As build assets are fingerprinted, we can set aggressive cache policies to ensure users have a fast experience on return visits
Not tied to any particular front-end framework
: Since your headless CMS is independent of your front-end, you can swap out your front-end framework as the front-end landscape evolves. I chose Next.js for this POC but there's also

— As Next.js makes no assumptions about the data layer and as your content is abstracted away into pure data accessed via API. Next.js (and most, if not all, SSR/SSG frameworks) is a back-end agnostic front-end framework, meaning minimal vendor entanglement. Migration between headless CMS providers would be relatively painless, giving you that flexibility if another provider comes along with a substantially better offering worth migrating for. The
shows the same site implemented with eight different headless CMS providers and the set of minimal changes required to do that.

— Since the only required infrastructure for this stack is essentially object storage, edge functions and a docker container for the preview server, you can easily move between cloud providers. Fits with in with the org move to Azure with a stack built on
Ability to choose the best-in-class solutions

— Move away from your monolothic CMS doing everything. Instead, choose the most  powerful, most advanced tool for the job. e.g. Optimizely for A/B testing, Segment for Analytics, Contentful to manage your data. Since you're not stuck using what will integrate with your CMS, use whatever the best tool there is.
Queryable via GraphQL — Consumers can query content APIs for exactly what they require
Clients and SDKs provided for multiple languages, frameworks and platforms (e.g.
— The hiring pool of AEM developers is relatively small. With the move to an OSS-based fronted, your hiring pool opens up significantly as Melbourne already has a large
of talented, passionate front-end developers. There's no longer a need to undertake a global search for hiring when there's already exceptional talent close to home.

— With a headless CMS all of your content is already structured and 
organised. We can leverage this with our search provider by creating  more intelligent search results that index the pure content according our predefined schema, rather than scraping content from rendered pages and trying to make sense of the structure (See

for the drawbacks of content organised in 'blobs'). Also, since we can respond to publish/unpublish events via webhooks in our headless CMS, we can trigger a rebuild of the search index to run asynchronously, ensuring our search results are always up to date.
Simplified servicing of legal requests / maintaining compliance

— With each publish and subsequent build of the site, you get a snapshot of the site at that point in time that you can then archive since the output is just static files. This makes servicing requests for past versions of the site painless; all a developer has to do is find the required build in S3 and forward it to legal. You could even standup a Wayback Machine-like service that proxies date-time requests to the appropriate archive.
A repeatable pattern of creating and developing new sites
— As mentioned in the author experience, above.

— Images are by far the largest asset type on our sites, and it's not uncommon to come across 3MB+ images being used as thumbnails (noticied via the AppD performance dashboard). With this solution and section-based components, we know the image context (i.e. dimensions through all breakpoints) ahead of time. We can then leverage headless CMS image APIs (for example, DatoCMS uses
, Contentful provides their own API) to serve an appropriately size image across all viewports and pixel densities.
URLs as the primitive for collaboration
" — Every push and pull request receives a shareable URL, allowing cross-org collaboration between stakeholders, designers, developers, a11y, marketing and legal.

When you have a deploy URL, it redefines not just testing, but  the entire software development experience, from idea to conception to QA.  Now you’re testing against the real thing. You get a working URL that can be  shared and tested as a full working version. You eliminate the entire staging process. —

— Automated performance testing via Lighthouse helps you start with a high performance baseline, and ensures you don't slip below predefined performance budgets. If someone wants to add something to the site that'll hurt performance the build fails and developers can discuss is it justifiable or are there alternatives that don't impact the user experience? It makes performance hits opt-in, rather than something that suffers over time. Lighthouse also provides accessibility, SEO, PWA and best practices auditing.
— As all site content is available at build time, we can generate Open Graph / Twitter card images used in social channels automatically, or standup a
or edge function to generate the images at request time (and cache the result).
Authored redirects handled via Edge functions
—  Eliminates the need to run, patch and maintain a web server. See
A Static Future — The magic of compile-time workflows
Static Hoisting — SSG vs a CDN-fronted server
Gatsby Days: How We Got Here and The Future of Website Development

description.en-US: An overview of how everything fits together

content.value: Some notes and additional context the helps in understanding a headless CMS-based architecture and the ideas presented in subsequent articles.

A headless CMS is content management software that enables writers to produce and organize content, while providing developers with structured data that can be displayed using a separate system on the frontend of a website or app. A traditional, monolithic CMS is responsible for both the backend management of content, and serving that content to end users. In contrast, a headless CMS is decoupled from frontend concerns, which frees developers to build rich experiences for end users, using the best technology available. —

Monolithic CMS platforms commonly used today don't work well for teams that
employ agile development practices such as Infrastructure as Code and
Continuous Delivery. Provisioning, migrating and testing those platforms is
inherently difficult to automate
from Brad Frost goes into more detail on this design system model.
